entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 16 at 5:21AM CDT until August 16 at 12:00PM CDT by NWS Springfield MO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, and southwest Missouri, including the following counties, in central Missouri, Pulaski. In south central Missouri, Howell and Texas. In southwest Missouri, Douglas, Laclede and Wright.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 521 AM CDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated that between 3 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. Flooding impacts will continue, but no additional rainfall is expected. - This includes the following low water crossings... Elk Creek at Highway Z, North Fork River at Highway EE, Big Piney River at Cleveland Road, North Fork River at County Road 278, Little Piney River at Union Road, Wolf Creek at Highway AB and Beaver Creek at Crewes Ford Road. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Fort Leonard Wood, West Plains, Waynesville, Mountain Grove, Willow Springs, Houston, St. Robert, Cabool, Richland, Mansfield, Crocker, Norwood, Hartville, Morgan, Dawson, Pomona, Huggins, Plato, Twin Bridges, Graff, Bendavis, Manes, Lynchburg, Success, Roby, Competition, Bucyrus, Falcon, Hazelton, Simmons, Elk Creek, Dry Knob, Solo, Grovespring, Odin, Laquey, Ozark Springs, Devil's Elbow and Siloam Springs. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Douglas, MO; Howell, MO; Laclede, MO; Pulaski, MO; Texas, MO; Wright, MO

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 16 at 5:18AM CDT until August 16 at 7:45AM CDT by NWS Springfield MO
entry.summary:
At 518 AM CDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms produced heavy rain across the warned area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. Flooding impacts will continue, but no additional rainfall is expected. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Seymour, Fordland, Diggins, Duncan and Northview.
This includes the following low water crossings... Panther Creek at Highway B, Panther Creek at North Iron Mountain Road and James River at Bell Ford Road.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Webster, MO

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 16 at 2:52AM PDT until August 17 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* IMPACTS...Strong winds combined with critically low relative humidity can lead to the rapid growth and spread of new and existing fires.
* AFFECTED AREA...Much of Fire Weather Zone 625 south of Summer Lake and the Christmas Valley. This includes the Warner Peak Fire, Adel, Paisley and the Hart Mountain Refuge.
* WIND...South winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts 30 to 40 mph, and gusts up to 45 mph on the ridges.
* HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Desert including the BLM Land in Eastern Lake and Western Harney Counties

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 16 at 2:51AM PDT until August 17 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
...HOT, DRY, WINDY, AND POTENTIALLY UNSTABLE CONDITIONS EXPECTED FOR SOUTHEASTERN OREGON ON SATURDAY...
.A robust low pressure system centered off the coast of the Pacific Northwest will orient the winds aloft more southerly, pushing in a hot and dry airmass into southern Oregon. Relative humidities will drop significantly as a result on Saturday. This, combined with the low pressure system amplifying the wind speeds, will potentially lead to critical fire weather conditions across much of southeastern Oregon. Unstable conditions are possible as well, with values of 5 and locally 6 possible during the day Saturday.
The National Weather Service in Pendleton has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 642 Southern Blue and Strawberry Mountains.
* WINDS...South 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 8 percent.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds with dry conditions may lead to rapid fire spread. Unstable conditions may promote extreme fire behavior as well.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Blue and Strawberry Mountains

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE OR642

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 16 at 4:19AM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
Areas of locally dense fog will affect areas around the Twin Ports and the North Shore this morning, especially in the higher terrain. Visibilities of 1/2 to 1/4 mile have already been observed, which should persist through the early morning hours. Visibilities are expected to improve after sunrise. If traveling early this morning, reduce your speed and use low-beam headlights when encountering foggy areas.
A Dense Fog Advisory may be needed. Keep updated on the latest forecast for fog development trends.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Lake/North Shore; Southern Cook/North Shore; Carlton/South St. Louis

cap:parameter.value: LOCALLY DENSE FOG AFFECTING THE TWIN PORTS AND NORTH SHORE THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 16 at 1:12AM AKDT until August 18 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE... Rivers and streams along the southern Seward Peninsula, including the Snake River in Nome, Niukluk River in Council, as well as impacting the road to Teller and the Nome-Council road. This includes the cities of Nome, White Mountain, Golovin, Serpentine Hot Springs, Council, Haycock, Pilgrim Springs, And Taylor.
* WHEN...Through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain is expected to continue over the southern Seward Peninsula through Friday morning from a strong storm system over the Bering Sea. Rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 2.5 inches are expected through Friday along the southern Seward Peninsula from Nome to Koyuk. A second system arriving Saturday morning will bring an additional 1 to 1.5 inches of rain to the aforementioned area, bringing total rainfall amounts through next Monday to around 2.5 to 4 inches. This rain will fall on already saturated soils from heavy rain earlier this month. Expect flooding of smaller creeks and streams in the area including but not limited to the Snake and Niukluk Rivers. Additionally, heavy rain could potentially impact crossings on the road to Council and the road to Teller.
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
- Stay away from steep barren hillsides due to the landslide danger.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 16 at 1:12AM AKDT until August 19 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Northern , including the following areas, Noatak Valley, South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range and Upper Kobuk Valleys. This includes the cities of Walker Lake, Noatak, Red Dog Mine, Ambler, Shungnak, And Kobuk.
* WHEN...Through Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Total precipitation through Monday is expected to be between 3 to 6 inches across the area, with the heaviest rainfall amounts expected along the southern slopes of the western Brooks Range. Expect rapid rises and flooding along smaller rivers and streams draining the western Brooks Range through the weekend. Heavy rainfall will also cause the Kobuk River to rise through next week, with the river potentially reaching flood stage by early next week.
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Noatak Valley; Upper Kobuk Valleys

* WHERE...Tar River at Tarboro.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 16 at 3:21AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Triple digit heat index values are expected again this afternoon over southeast Missouri, the Purchase Area of Kentucky, and adjacent portions of southern Illinois. The worst conditions are expected over the Ozark Foothills, where readings could reach 110 degrees. Farther to the northeast heat index values are expected to range from 95 to 100 degrees, but triple digit readings will be possible throughout the region. A Heat Advisory may eventually be issued for a portion of the region if confidence improves.
Use caution if planning to be outdoors for extended periods of time. Take frequent breaks, drink plenty of water, and wear light colored clothing.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 16 at 1:16AM PDT until August 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Las Vegas NV
entry.summary:
Southerly to southwesterly winds will increase over the weekend as a trough digs along the West Coast. These winds combined with afternoon relative humidities around 10% to 15% and dry fuels will result in critical fire weather conditions across Esmeralda and Nye Counties in southern Nevada. Winds will drop off and relative humidities will recover Saturday night into Sunday morning before critical conditions return Sunday afternoon.
The National Weather Service in Las Vegas has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from 11 AM Saturday to 8 PM PDT Sunday. This replaces the Fire Weather Watch which had been in effect.
* AFFECTED AREA...In Nevada...Fire weather zones 460 and 462.
* TIMING...1100 AM PDT Saturday through 800 PM PDT Sunday.
* WIND...15 to 25 mph southerly winds with gusts around 35 mph.
* HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Esmeralda and Nye County Deserts/CNC Dispatch; Nye County Deserts/Las Vegas Dispatch

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 4:05AM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services has issued an Air Quality Alert for particle pollution until midnight EDT tonight.
The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services is predicting unhealthy air quality in the above-mentioned counties. Sensitive individuals include children and older adults; anyone with lung disease such as asthma, emphysema, and bronchitis; and people who are active outdoors. Even healthy individuals may experience mild health effects and should consider limiting strenuous or prolonged outdoor activities.
For additional information, please visit the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Prediction website at, https://www4.des.state.nh.us/airdata/

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 16 at 3:01AM CDT until August 16 at 8:00AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
FFWPAH
The National Weather Service in Paducah has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Northwestern Butler County in southeastern Missouri... Carter County in southeastern Missouri... Northern Ripley County in southeastern Missouri... South Central Wayne County in southeastern Missouri...
* Until 800 AM CDT.
* At 301 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Poplar Bluff, Ellsinore, Williamsville, Budapest, Hunter, Brush Arbor, Milltown, Hendrickson, Handy, Fremont and Grandin.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butler, MO; Carter, MO; Ripley, MO; Wayne, MO

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 2:51AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
The Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection has issued an Air Quality Alert for Fine Particulates, until midnight EDT tonight.
An Air Quality Alert means that Fine Particulates concentrations within the region may approach or exceed levels that are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups.
Air is unhealthy for sensitive children and adults, such as those with asthma, lung or heart disease, and older adults. Sensitive children and adults should limit prolonged outdoor activity.
For additional information, please visit the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection website at: https://mass.gov/orgs/massachusetts-department-of-environmental- protection
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Franklin; Eastern Franklin; Northern Worcester; Western Hampshire; Western Hampden; Eastern Hampshire; Eastern Hampden; Southern Worcester

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 16 at 12:24AM AST until August 16 at 8:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Guanajibo River and small stream flooding caused by excessive runoff from previous days rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of Puerto Rico, including the following counties, Cabo Rojo, Hormigueros and Mayaguez.Along Rio Guanajibo and tributaries.
* WHEN...Until 800 AM AST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water. It will take several hours for all the water from these storms to work through local drainage systems in urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1224 AM AST, Emergency management reported roads 114 remained flooded and portions of it blocked off due to waters on roads. Runoff continues as the Guanajibo steadily drains. - Flooding impacts will continue, but no additional rainfall is expected. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 15 at 4:56PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Today's storm will continue to bring rain, strong winds, and coastal impacts across Southwest Alaska through tomorrow morning, with the worst impacts expected for the Kuskokwim Delta coast. A Coastal Flood Advisory is in effect for the Kuskokwim Bay and west from this evening through Sunday night. As this first storm weakens and exits towards the north, rain will taper off and winds will weaken by late tomorrow morning.
The second of three major storms arrives in Southwest Alaska Friday evening. Generally, expect similar or slightly improved conditions for the second storm as compared to the first storm:
- Rain: 1 to 1.25 inches of rain are forecast along the immediate coastline, with 0.5 to 1 inch for the rest of Kuskokwim Delta and Bristol Bay. For the Lower Kuskokwim Valley, up to 0.50 inches.
- Winds: Sustained southerly winds up to gale force along the front on Saturday, with a longer duration of onshore flow than the first storm. Winds wrapping back around the low and into Kuskokwim Delta on Sunday morning could be as strong as tonight's winds, with gusts as high as 50-60 mph.
- Surge: Coastal Flood Advisory remains in effect through Sunday night for Kuskokwim Bay and west. Elevated coastal water levels could persist through several tide cycles. Strong, sustained winds could limit the retreat of water during low tide. Less impactful surge is expected for the Bristol Bay coastline.
- Preparedness: Secure loose belongings and move items further inland away from water. Monitor the forecast as strong, back- to-back storms impact Southwest Alaska through the middle of next week.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kuskokwim Valley; Kuskokwim Delta; Bristol Bay

cap:parameter.value: FIRST STORM IMPACTS SOUTHWEST ALASKA THROUGH TOMORROW MORNING, THEN SECOND STORM ARRIVES TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 15 at 4:18PM AKDT until August 18 at 11:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Anchorage has issued a Coastal Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 6 PM this evening to 11 PM AKDT Sunday.
* LOCATION...Kuskokwim Bay and west, especially the communities of Kongiganak, Kwigillingok, and Kipnuk.
* COASTAL FLOODING...Water levels will rise as high as 3 to 6 feet above normal highest tide. While water levels will drop during low tide, expect higher than usual water levels to return during high tide.
* TIMING...From 6 PM this evening through 11 PM Sunday as several rounds of strong winds impact the Kuskokwim Delta coast. The timing of highest water levels will depend on tide cycles at your location. Generally, the strongest winds are expected: (1) late this afternoon through Friday morning; (2) Friday night through Saturday morning; and (3) early Sunday morning through Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding of low lying areas along the coast. Strong winds, high surf, and wave run-up could move property along the shoreline. Coastal erosion is possible. Strong, sustained winds could slow the retreat of water during low tide.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Moderate to heavy rain from today's storm and this weekend's storm could also contribute to elevated water levels.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta

entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall of 2-4 inches is expected through Sunday afternoon with heavier amounts possible mainly on the Southern Seward Peninsula and higher elevation areas across the Interior. Southerly winds increase to Gale force tonight then veer westerly Friday morning, especially in the Norton Sound. High water levels along the coast are expected on Friday, with minor coastal flooding possible.
Pay close attention to updates on the next storm expected late in the weekend. Expected rainfall accumulations, sea conditions and wind speeds may need to be adjusted.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg

ESFAFG
Total precipitation through Monday is expected to be between 3 to 6 inches across the area, with the heaviest rainfall amounts expected along the southern slopes of the western Brooks Range. entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:08PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...Northwest Minnesota.
* WHEN...From 3 PM CDT Friday to 6 PM CDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota on Friday afternoon. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the Red River valley. Smoke will reach the border around 3 pm and arrive at the Fargo/Moorhead area around 6 pm Friday. Northerly winds will persist for several days and additional smoke is expected to move into northern Minnesota Saturday afternoon. The alert area may need to be expanded to account for additional areas that might be impacted by heavy smoke. Smoke will initially produce air quality in the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category Friday afternoon but levels may improve to the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category on Saturday. Smoke will linger until at least Sunday, as light northerly winds are expected to continue until Monday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Polk; Norman; Clay; Kittson; West Marshall; Wilkin

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 4:10PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Ozone Action Day Alert.
WHERE...Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, western Arapahoe, western Adams, Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer, and Weld Counties
WHEN...400 PM Thursday August 15 to 400 PM Friday August 16
IMPACTS...Ozone Action Day Alert is now in effect for the Front Range Urban Corridor. Request to limit driving gas and diesel- powered vehicles is now in effect until at least 4 p.m. Friday, August 16, 2024. Afternoon showers will limit ozone development on Thursday, and concentrations are expected to be in the Good to Moderate range. However, hot, dry and stagnant weather will allow Ozone to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Category on Friday.For areas included in this advisory that are not expected to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (USG) air quality designation, we request that activities, such as driving non-ZEV vehicles (i.e., gas or diesel), be reduced to lessen the impacts on neighboring air quality. Additional air pollution in this region may directly worsen air quality or contribute to precursors which may also adversely affect air quality. For Colorado air quality conditions, forecasts and advisories, visit: https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx
HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:38PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
The Maine Department of Environmental Protection's Bureau of Air Quality has issued an Air Quality Alert for particle pollution until 11 PM EDT this evening.
Particle pollution levels are expected to continue in the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups range into this evening in the Northern region. A large plume of smoke from various Canadian fires has pushed into Maine and is expected to linger at least through this evening. Currently, the alert is only for the Northern region but we are keeping an eye on conditions. While the remainder of the state is expected to be Moderate for particle pollution the effects of heat and humidity will exacerbate the health impacts from smoke.
The Maine Department of Environmental Protection recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young, the elderly, those with pre-existing respiratory problems such as asthma, those with heart disease and anyone who is working hard outdoors. But if you experience symptoms such as shortness of breath, coughing, throat irritation or an uncomfortable sensation in your chest please consider limiting the intensity and duration of your outdoor activities.
A toll free air quality hotline has been established so Maine residents can stay informed on the air quality situations. The toll free number is: 1-800-223-1196.
Additionally the Maine Department of Environmental Protection has the air quality forecast available on the web at www.maine.gov/dep/air/aqforecast.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:36PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
The Vermont Agency of Natural Resources has issued an Air Quality Health Advisory for Code Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category due to Fine Particulates for Vermont from midnight tonight to midnight EDT Friday night.
The air quality index, or AQI, is expected to approach or exceed the Code Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category due to Fine Particulates.
When pollution levels are in the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category, the Vermont Department of Health recommends that these individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects.
People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young, older adults, and those with preexisting respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease and those working outside.
Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
People with asthma should follow their asthma action plans and keep quick relief medicine handy.
If you have heart disease: symptoms such as palpitations, shortness of breath, or unusual fatigue may indicate a serious problem. If you have any of these, contact your healthcare provider.
An Air Quality Action Day means that particulate concentrations within the region may approach or exceed unhealthy standards.
For additional information, please visit the Vermont Agency of Natural Resources web site at https://dec.vermont.gov/air-quality/local-air-quality-forecasts.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 15 at 1:09PM EDT until August 16 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring along the lower reaches of the Ogeechee River.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast Georgia, including the following counties, Bryan and Chatham.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding along the lower Ogeechee River is inundating roads and businesses near Richmond Hill.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 105 PM EDT, emergency management reported ongoing flooding in the warned area. - USGS gages on the Ogeechee River near Ellabell and Richmond Hill indicate that peak water levels have passed and continue to fall. However, flooding continues in and around the Richmond Hill area. Chatham County Emergency Management indicates that the flooding is subsiding on the Chatham County and Byran County side of the river. Please continue to avoid flooded roadways and heed any remaining road closures. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Richmond Hill, Burroughs, Brisbon, Port Royal and Rabbit Hill.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bryan, GA; Chatham, GA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 130 PM EDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 15 at 12:36PM EDT until August 16 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continued to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County between State Road 53 and the Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 and 262. All of the flooding is due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby. Expect new flooded areas as water continues to slowly move to the south and east across Madison County.
* WHERE...Southeast Madison County in the Florida Big Bend.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Some homes are flooded, numerous roads are impacted or closed, and a campground near Exit 258 are affected at this time. Additional roads will likely become impassible. Interstate 10 is currently not affected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1234 PM EDT, emergency management reported flooding in the warned area. Flooding is already occurring. - Flooding will likely persist through the at least this week due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby last week. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee and Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison, FL

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 14 at 1:06PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Pollution Advisory...in effect until at least 3 PM PDT Friday.
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued an air quality advisory for Lake and northern Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in eastern Douglas and Jackson County through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Klamath, OR; Lake, OR

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM PDT FRIDAY
